bestBHT.bht: In his closing remarks, Peter confronts his listeners with the undeniable truth that it was they who crucified Jesus. By doing so, Peter intends to stir a deep sense of compunction and lead them towards seeking forgiveness for their sin. Proving that Jesus is the Messiah alone might not have been enough; Peter's aim was to convince them that the crucified Jesus is now exalted at the right hand of God. This powerful message calls for reflection and repentance, recognizing Jesus as both Lord and Christ.

Henry Alford: The final clause sets in the strongest and plainest light the fact to which the discourse testifies—ending with whom ye crucified,—the remembrance most likely to carry compunction to their hearts.
In the close of his discourse, he again reproaches them with His crucifixion, that they may be touched with the greater compunction of conscience, and may be eager to seek the remedy for their sin.
Bengel calls this 'the sting at the end' of the discourse.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: To prove to them merely that Jesus was the Messiah might have left them all unchanged in heart. But to convince them that He whom they had crucified had been by the right hand of God exalted, and constituted the 'LORD' whom David in spirit adored, to whom every knee shall bow, and the CHRIST of God, was to bring them to 'look on Him whom they had pierced and mourn for Him.'
The sting is at the close.

Be assured, or know without any hesitation or possibility of mistake. This is the sum of his argument or his discourse. He had established the points which he purposed to prove, and he now applies it to his hearers.
There is nothing better suited to make sinners fear and tremble than to show them that, in rejecting Christ, they have rejected God; in refusing to serve him they have refused to serve God.
Marvin Vincent: Assuredly [ασφαλως] . From aj, not, and sfallw, to cause to fall. Hence, firmly, steadfastly.

For the putting of him to death was not only full of cruelty and wickedness, but also a testimony of outrageous disloyalty against God, of sacrilege and unthankfulness, and, finally, of apostasy.

He showed from a passage in Joel, well known to his listeners, that the outpouring of the Spirit and its results, which they had just witnessed, was exactly what was foretold for the days of the Messiah.
This glorious One, now reigning with all power from His throne at the right hand of God, Messiah and King, is no other than that Jesus whom ye crucified.

bhtAttempts.bht: To conclude his discourse, Peter compels his listeners to confront the fact that it was they who crucified Jesus. By emphasizing this crucial detail, Peter aims to awaken compunction in their hearts and lead them to seek redemption for their sin. Merely proving that Jesus is the Messiah would not suffice in stirring a true change in their souls. Punctuating his speech with the gravity of their actions forces them to face the reality of their transgressions and mourn for the One they pierced. This sting at the end sets the stage for true repentance and a deep recognition of Jesus as both Lord and Christ, exalted by the right hand of God.

To conclude his discourse, Peter reproaches his listeners by reminding them that it was they who crucified Jesus. The intent behind this reminder is to elicit a profound sense of remorse and guilt so that they may be moved to seek a remedy for their sin. By demonstrating that the one they had crucified is now exalted at the right hand of God, Peter urges them to reflect upon their actions and seek redemption. This forceful emphasis on their role in crucifying Jesus serves as a poignant call to repentance and a recognition of Jesus as both Lord and Christ.

To bring a deep conviction to their hearts, Peter concludes his discourse by reproaching his listeners for the crucifixion of Jesus. By reminding them of their role in His death, Peter seeks to stir compunction and lead them to seek redemption. Understanding that the mere acknowledgment of Jesus as the Messiah might not have been sufficient, Peter emphasizes the exaltation of the One whom they had crucified by the right hand of God. This powerfully brings them to look on Him whom they had pierced and mourn for Him.
